page.title: 17"The changing landscape "
page.content: Since the late 1960's the most significant change in the local landscape has been the gradual encroachment on the Wreake valley and the areas surrounding East Goscote and Cossington, of the sand and gravel excavations.The first pit to be dug in the area,immediately adjacent to the Cossington Mill and south of the B5328,was allowed to fill with water after the initial exavation and has now become a thriving nature reserve and well-stocked fishing lake. It was decided,however,back in January 1979, that enough was enough and that no more pits or large artificial lakes were wanted and to this end 'The Cossington' Residents' Action Committee' was formed.It waged a vigorous campaign for over three years to preserve this delightful rural spot.By Mrs A Smith
